units.title: Cluster cells and assign annotations
units.text: We clustered cells at high resolution in each dataset and assigned cell annotations based on known marker gene expression and differential expression between clusters (Supplementary Table 2).
units.rationale: Describes the clustering and annotation step.

units.title: Three-level hierarchical cell-type annotation
units.text: We established a three-level hierarchical cell-type annotation: class (level 1), type (level 2) and subtype (level 3) (Fig. 2a,b), and compared organoid cell types and states with primary tissue counterparts using neighborhood graph correlation24.

units.title: Assess integration methods and select scPoli
units.text: To address batch effects and achieve a robust integration, we assessed 12 different data-integration methods using the proportion of cell types in each organoid sample and compared the similarity of each cell type with counterparts in adult and fetal tissues, and selected scPoli to generate an integrated embedding of all organoid cells.
units.rationale: Details evaluation and selection of integration method.

units.title: Generate integrated embedding of organoid cells
units.text: We selected scPoli20,22 to generate an integrated embedding of all organoid cells, enabling a cohesive representation of the diverse data (Fig. 1e and Extended Data Fig. 1e).

units.title: Reannotate integrated atlas based on most frequent cell type
units.text: The integrated atlas was reannotated based on the most frequent cell type in each cluster, resulting in 5 cell classes at level 1, 48 cell types at level 2 and 51 cell subtypes at level 3 (Fig. 1f–h).
units.rationale: Shows how final annotation was assigned.

units.title: Pseudo‑bulk analysis of organoid datasets
units.text: Pseudo‑bulk analysis using both raw and scPoli embedding on all organoid single‑cell datasets revealed stem cell source and tissue type as primary drivers of variance (Extended Data Fig. 4).

units.title: Subset and reintegrate intestinal organoid models
units.text: To explore organoid cell states of different stem cell origin, we focused on intestinal organoid models in which there is substantial coverage; we subsetted and reintegrated stem cells and enterocytes, and found that epithelial cells from different organs clustered together.
units.rationale: Focuses on a specific tissue analysis.

units.title: Quantify similarity to reference atlases
units.text: Multiple regression analyses revealed that similarity to reference atlases was influenced by publication and stem cell source but not by scRNA‑seq methods, total sample counts or total sample genes.
units.rationale: Provides assessment of factors affecting similarity.
